summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 discussing a Telegraph news article. The article reports that federal prosecutors from the SDNY requested a stay in a civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell, arguing it would jeopardize the ongoing criminal case against her. The civil suit, filed by a Jane Doe, contains allegations similar to the criminal indictment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The British heiress facing child sex trafficking charges. Prosecutors argue a civil lawsuit against her should be halted as it overlaps with and could jeopardize the criminal case.

persons.name: Josie Ensor
persons.context: Byline author of the Telegraph article that is the subject of the email chain.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.context: Pseudonym for the woman, now 40, who filed the civil lawsuit. She alleges she was groomed by Epstein and Maxwell starting at age 13 and subjected to years of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Robert Glassman
persons.context: Lawyer representing Jane Doe in the civil suit. He wrote to the court arguing against a stay, stating his client is best served by pressing forward with her claims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The late financier who Maxwell allegedly groomed minor girls for. His estate is worth an estimated $577 million and is being sued by a number of his victims.

connections.description: Maxwell allegedly groomed three minor girls to be abused by Epstein in the mid-1990s. The civil plaintiff alleges she was approached by both Epstein and Maxwell.
Jane Doe's civil suit alleges Maxwell (along with Epstein) groomed her starting at age 13 and subjected her to years of sexual abuse.
Glassman is the lawyer representing Jane Doe in her civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell.
Both Maxwell and the co-executors of Epstein's estate have been arguing that the civil case should be placed on hold, aligning them with the government's position in this instance.

events.title: Alleged Initial Grooming of Jane Doe
events.description: Jane Doe alleges she was first approached at age 13 by Epstein and Maxwell at a summer camp in Michigan, beginning a months-long grooming process.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on multiple sex-trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his prison cell five weeks after his arrest.

events.title: Civil Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A civil lawsuit was filed against Ghislaine Maxwell under the pseudonym Jane Doe, containing allegations substantially similar to the criminal indictment.

events.title: SDNY Requests Stay in Civil Case
events.description: Federal prosecutors from the SDNY filed a letter arguing the civil lawsuit against Maxwell should be stayed as it overlaps with and jeopardizes the criminal prosecution.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors argued a civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell should be halted because its 'factual overlap' with the criminal case creates a 'significant risk' of jeopardizing the prosecution.
The civil plaintiff, Jane Doe, alleges she was groomed starting at age 13 in 1994 by both Epstein and Maxwell at a Michigan summer camp and then abused for years.
The government's position for a stay aligned them, in this instance, with both Maxwell and the co-executors of Epstein's estate.
Jeffrey Epstein's estate was valued at an estimated $577 million at the time of his death in August 2019.
A separate civil defamation case against Maxwell was also pending in a Manhattan court, involving a decision on whether to unseal 'sensitive' evidence.
